songs are out of door songs; spring songs; summer songs;
winter songs.
Bytuene Mersh and Averil
When spray biginneth to springe,
The lutel foul hath hire wyl
On hyre lud to synge.
Sumer is icumen in,
Lude sing cuccu
By a bank as I lay
Musing myself alone, hey ho!
A birdes voice
Did me rejoice,
Singing before the day;
And me thought in her lay
She said winter was past, hey ho!
They were out of door songs, because there was no
comfort indoors, little light, and no books. The eye
therefore was more active in in ourselves. The eye is the
young sense; the sense that is attached to the body.

Now and then, by 
            
              chooisng
              choosing
             a view carefully to shut out
a chimney or a bungalow, we can still see a fragment of
of what they saw-- a flat fen, reed whispering, water
logged; or a down still covered with turf only.
On the down is the green scar still, to mark the
road along which the travellers came, past the circle where
they were buried; past the stone that marks the meeting place
or the burial place.
but if Anon sings because love and spring make him
But
vocal or the horror of the winter dark, who listens? Somebody

It was the printed book with the authors name attached that
After that
was the death of Anon. The audience was separated from
the singer. After that ( 1478) the song was attached to
the singer. Anon gives place to James or Thomas; he lives in
in a house; and he has books.
The heart of this vast proliferation of printed

              bricks

Making whatever it is gives us life; and the passion
With which we seek for these creations, and attempt to
make them, is of a piece with the instinct that
sets us preserving our bodies from wet, or cold.
But with the printing press came into existence
forces that cover over the original song--books

they were buried; past the stone that marks the meeting place
or the burial place.
